verses.text: The proverbs of Solomon, son of David, king of Israel:
verses.comment: This introduction clearly attributes the following wisdom to Solomon, tying the collection to Israel's royal and divinely appointed lineage.

verses.text: to know wisdom and instruction, to understand words of insight,
verses.comment: True wisdom begins with a pursuit of understanding rooted in the fear of the Lord (see verse 7, and Isaiah 11:2 identifies wisdom as a gift of the Spirit).

verses.text: to receive instruction in wise dealing, in righteousness, justice, and equity;
verses.comment: The purpose of Proverbs is practical: to guide one in just and fair living, aspiring to God's own standards.

verses.text: to give prudence to the simple, knowledge and discretion to the youth—
verses.comment: This verse shows the importance of teaching the young, foreshadowing the church's historical emphasis on catechesis and formation.

verses.text: Let the wise hear and increase in learning, and the one who understands obtain guidance—
verses.comment: No one outgrows the need for wisdom or correction; this highlights the virtue of humility.

verses.text: to understand a proverb and a saying, the words of the wise and their riddles.
verses.comment: Jesus' use of parables echoes this tradition, revealing truths in layers to those open to deeper meaning.

verses.text: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge; fools despise wisdom and instruction.
verses.comment: Reverence for God is the foundation of true knowledge. The concept points toward the necessity of awe, humility, and receptivity, all core to authentic faith and relationship with God.

verses.text: Hear, my son, your father's instruction, and do not forsake your mother's teaching,
verses.comment: Instruction from both parents is emphasized, foreshadowing the honor due to family and tradition.

verses.text: for they are a graceful garland for your head and chains for your neck.
verses.comment: Wisdom and instruction are compared with visible adornments, expressing their public and lasting rewards.

verses.text: My son, if sinners entice you, do not consent.
verses.comment: A personal exhortation against peer pressure and the lure of sin, resonating with Psalms’ call for the righteous to remain distinct from sinners.

verses.text: If they say, 'Come with us, let us lie in wait for blood; let us ambush the innocent without reason;
verses.comment: Solomon warns against joining with the violent or plotting against the innocent, a theme echoed in the prophets.

verses.text: let us swallow them alive like Sheol, whole, like those who go down to the pit;
verses.comment: Violence is depicted as leading directly to the grave—a warning that evil ultimately devours its own.

verses.text: we shall find all precious goods, we shall fill our houses with plunder;
verses.comment: The pursuit of unjust gain is condemned repeatedly in wisdom literature.

verses.text: throw in your lot among us; we will all have one purse"—
verses.comment: The temptation here echoes later betrayals for money, such as Judas’s in the Gospels.

verses.text: my son, do not walk in the way with them; hold back your foot from their paths,
verses.comment: A call not merely to refuse evil, but to actively avoid walking the path of the wicked.

verses.text: for their feet run to evil, and they are quick to shed blood.
verses.comment: Isaiah later references this passage to condemn Israel's accumulated guilt.

verses.text: For in vain is a net spread in the sight of any bird,
verses.comment: Sinners are blind to the danger of their own schemes.

verses.text: but these men lie in wait for their own blood; they set an ambush for their own lives.
verses.comment: Evil ultimately turns back upon those who plot it.

verses.text: Such are the ways of everyone who is greedy for unjust gain; it takes away the life of its possessors.
verses.comment: Greed for unjust gain is called the 'root of all evil' in the New Testament, reinforcing this warning.

verses.text: Wisdom cries aloud in the street, in the public squares she raises her voice;
verses.comment: Wisdom is personified here, later viewed by many as prefiguring the divine Logos who speaks to humanity (cf. John 1:1-5).

verses.text: at the head of the noisy streets she calls, at the entrance of the city gates she speaks:
verses.comment: God’s wisdom is available and visible; no one can claim ignorance.

verses.text: "How long, O simple ones, will you love being simple? How long will scoffers delight in their scoffing and fools hate knowledge?
verses.comment: Repeated rejection of wisdom hardens hearts—a motif echoed throughout the Bible.

verses.text: If you turn at my rebuke, behold, I will pour out my spirit to you; I will make my words known to you.
verses.comment: True repentance brings spiritual outpouring; a foreshadowing of Pentecost where God pours out the Spirit.

verses.text: Because I have called and you refused to listen, have stretched out my hand and no one has heeded,
verses.comment: God’s patient persistence is rejected at great peril.

verses.text: because you have ignored all my counsel and would have none of my rebuke,
verses.comment: Ignoring correction leaves one exposed to folly.

verses.text: I also will laugh at your disaster; I will mock when terror strikes you,
verses.comment: A warning: refusing grace leads to judgment.

verses.text: when terror strikes you like a storm and your disaster comes like a whirlwind, when distress and anguish come upon you.
verses.comment: Calamity is the natural outcome of ignoring divine instruction.

verses.text: Then they will call upon me, but I will not answer; they will seek me diligently but will not find me.
verses.comment: A sober reminder to seek God while He may be found; similar language is used by Jesus of the closed door.

verses.text: Because they hated knowledge and did not choose the fear of the LORD,
verses.comment: Willful rejection, not ignorance, is condemned.

verses.text: would have none of my counsel and despised all my correction,
verses.comment: God's corrective discipline is vital for true wisdom and holiness.

verses.text: therefore they shall eat the fruit of their way, and be sated with their own schemes.
verses.comment: A person reaps what he sows, a justice that is both temporal and eternal.

verses.text: For the turning away of the simple will kill them, and the complacency of fools destroys them;
verses.comment: Moral neutrality or passivity is spiritually fatal.

verses.text: but whoever listens to me will dwell secure and will be at ease, without fear of evil."
verses.comment: Listening and obedience bring steadfast security. See Matthew 7 for Jesus’ teaching on building on a firm foundation, highlighting the importance of rightly responding to wisdom and grace.
